sentences: Williams began his music career in Montgomery in 1937, when producers at local radio station WSFA hired him to perform and host a 15-minute program.
In 1947, he released "Move It on Over", which became a hit, and also joined the Louisiana Hayride radio program.
In 1952, he divorced Sheppard and married singer Billie Jean Horton.
Williams was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1961, the Songwriters Hall of Fame in 1970, and the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame in 1987.

The Pulitzer Prize jury awarded him a posthumous special citation in 2010 for his "craftsmanship as a songwriter who expressed universal feelings with poignant simplicity and played a pivotal role in transforming country music into a major musical and cultural force in American life".
Williams was born Hiram Williams on September 17, 1923, in the rural community of Mount Olive in Butler County, Alabama.
The family's first child, Ernest Huble Williams, was born on July 5, 1921; he died two days later.
In 1930, when Williams was seven years old, Elonzo began suffering from facial paralysis.
In the fall of 1934, the Williams family moved to Greenville, Alabama, where Lillie opened a boarding house next to the Butler County courthouse.

In 1935, they settled in Garland, Alabama, where Lillie opened a new boarding house; they later moved with Williams's cousin Opal McNeil to Georgiana, Alabama, where Lillie took several side jobs to support the family despite the bleak economic climate of the Great Depression.
In 1937, Williams got into a fight with his physical education teacher about exercises the coach wanted him to do.
Payne and Williams lost touch, though Payne also eventually moved to Montgomery, where he died in poverty in 1939.
In July 1937, the Williams and McNeils opened a boarding house on South Perry Street in downtown Montgomery.

So many listeners contacted the radio station asking for more of "the singing kid", possibly influenced by his mother, that the producers hired him to host his own 15-minute show twice a week for a weekly salary of US$15 (equivalent to $300 in 2020).
In August 1938, Elonzo Williams was temporarily released from the hospital.
Williams dropped out of school in October 1939 so that he and the Drifting Cowboys could work full-time.
The American entry into World War II in 1941 marked the beginning of hard times for Williams.
He continued to show up for his radio show intoxicated, so in August 1942 the WSFA radio station fired him for "habitual drunkenness".
In 1943, Williams met Audrey Sheppard at a medicine show in Banks, Alabama.
The couple were married in 1944 at a Texaco Station in Andalusia, Alabama, by a justice of the peace.
In 1945, when he was back in Montgomery, Williams started to perform again for the WSFA radio station.
On September 14, 1946, Williams auditioned for Nashville's Grand Ole Opry, but was rejected.

On December 11, 1946, in his first recording session, he recorded "Wealth Won't Save Your Soul", "Calling You", "Never Again (Will I Knock on Your Door)", and "When God Comes and Gathers His Jewels", which was misprinted as "When God Comes and Fathers His Jewels".
Williams signed with MGM Records in 1947 and released "Move It on Over"; considered an early example of rock and roll music, the song became a massive country hit.
In 1948, he moved to Shreveport, Louisiana, and he joined the Louisiana Hayride, a radio show broadcast that propelled him into living rooms all over the Southeast appearing on weekend shows.
After a few more moderate hits, in 1949 he released his version of the 1922 Cliff Friend and Irving Mills song "Lovesick Blues", made popular by Rex Griffin.
On June 11, 1949, Williams made his debut at the Grand Ole Opry, where he became the first performer to receive six encores.

He brought together Bob McNett (guitar), Hillous Butrum (bass), Jerry Rivers (fiddle) and Don Helms (steel guitar) to form the most famous version of the Drifting Cowboys, earning an estimated $1,000 per show (equivalent to $10,900 in 2020)
During 1949, he joined the first European tour of the Grand Ole Opry, performing in military bases in England, Germany and the Azores.
In 1950, Williams began recording as "Luke the Drifter" for his religious-themed recordings, many of which are recitations rather than singing.
In 1951, "Dear John" became a hit, but it was the flip side, "Cold, Cold Heart", that became one of his most recognized songs.
Williams's career reached a peak in the late summer of 1951 with his Hadacol tour of the U.S. with Bob Hope and other actors.
On November 14, 1951, Williams flew to New York with his steel guitar player Don Helms where he appeared on television for the first time on The Perry Como Show.
In November 1951, Williams suffered a fall during a hunting trip with his fiddler Jerry Rivers in Franklin, Tennessee.
On December 13, 1951, he had a spinal fusion at the Vanderbilt University Hospital, being released on December 24.
During the spring of 1952, Williams flew to New York with steel guitarist Don Helms, where he made two appearances with other Grand Ole Opry members on The Kate Smith Show.
In June 1952, he recorded "Jambalaya (On the Bayou)", "Window Shopping", "Settin' the Woods on Fire", and "I'll Never Get out of this World Alive".
On August 11, 1952, Williams was dismissed from the Grand Ole Opry for habitual drunkenness and missing shows.
In October 1952 he married Billie Jean Jones.
During his last recording session on September 23, 1952, Williams recorded "Kaw-Liga", along with "Your Cheatin' Heart", "Take These Chains from My Heart", and "I Could Never be Ashamed of You".
Marshall had been previously convicted for forgery, and had been paroled and released from the Oklahoma State Penitentiary in 1951.

He was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 1961 and into the Alabama Music Hall of Fame in 1985.

In 1964, Hank Williams was portrayed by George Hamilton in the film Your Cheatin' Heart.
In 1977, a national organization of CB truck drivers voted "Your Cheatin' Heart" as their favorite record of all time.
In 1987, he was inducted in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame under the category "Early Influence".
He was ranked second in CMT's 40 Greatest Men of Country Music in 2003, behind only Johnny Cash who recorded the song "The Night Hank Williams Came To Town".
In 2004, Rolling Stone ranked him number 74 on its list of the 100 Greatest Artists of All Time.
In 2011, Williams's 1949 MGM number one hit, "Lovesick Blues", was inducted into the Recording Academy Grammy Hall of Fame.

In 1999, Williams was inducted into the Native American Music Hall of Fame.

On April 12, 2010, the Pulitzer Prize Board awarded Williams a posthumous special citation that paid tribute to his "craftsmanship as a songwriter who expressed universal feelings with poignant simplicity and played a pivotal role in transforming country music into a major musical and cultural force in American life".
In July 2020, his granddaughter Katherine (Hank Jr.'s daughter) died in a car crash at the age of 27.
His great-grandson Coleman Finchum, son of Hank Williams III, released his debut single credited to IV and the Strange Band in 2021.
In 2006, a janitor of Sony/ATV Music Publishing found in a dumpster the unfinished lyrics written by Williams that had been found in his car the night he died.
The unfinished lyrics were later returned to Sony/ATV, which handed them to Bob Dylan in 2008 to complete the songs for a new album.
The album, named The Lost Notebooks of Hank Williams, was released on October 4, 2011.
In 1993, a double-disc set of recordings of Williams for the Health & Happiness Show was released.
